title: Massive Cuts to NIH and Cancer Research Funding
summary: The Trump administration cut $2.7 billion from NIH funding in early 2025, including a 31% decrease in cancer research. Proposed 2026 budget would slash NIH by 40% ($18 billion) and cut National Cancer Institute by 37% ($2.69 billion). Officials terminated 5,844 already-funded NIH grants in unprecedented move.
keyFacts: $2.7 billion cut from NIH funding in first 3 months of 2025
Cancer research funding decreased 31% compared to 2024
5,844 NIH grants and 1,996 NSF grants cancelled or suspended - unprecedented action
Proposed 2026 budget would cut NIH by nearly $18 billion (40% reduction to $27.5 billion)
National Cancer Institute budget would drop from $7.22 billion to $4.53 billion (37.3% cut)
Officials began terminating already-funded grants at NIH in February 2025
Represents largest rollback of federal support for medical research in American history
Puts current and future cancer patients at risk according to medical experts
Leukemia & Lymphoma Society: 'These cuts will have devastating consequences for patients'
Congress ultimately rejected cuts, increasing NIH budget by $415 million instead
